Why isn't `__attribute__((cleanup(...)))` more known?
description:
The gcc extension __attribute__((cleanup(...))) is supported by clang as well, meaning at least in the Linux world it’s a viable way to manage memory and other resources. Yet no one talks about it and the Linux people are going so far as to try Rust for memory safety. My question: why not try __attribute__((cleanup(...))) first? Eg

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

#define defer(F) __attribute__((cleanup(F)))

void freep(char** p) {
  if (*p == NULL) return;

  free(*p);
  *p = NULL;
}

int main() {
  char* msg defer(freep) = malloc(16);
}

We spoke to Great Expectations about the library's DX
description:
I work for Sparkfish, a data and analytics consultancy serving private equity.

For context, GE is a data quality library used by data and ML engineers and other folks who work with data; it’s the largest library by far in terms of community buy-in and feature set. But like many we’ve struggled with the difficult learning curve of the GX library and the deprioritization of the open source library vs the paid SaaS product, and we griped about it publicly in various forums and on GH issues. Mainly we’ve struggled with the steep learning curve, obtuse APIs, lack of sensible defaults, and dated documentation.

It’s a great library and surprisingly one of few truly focused on data quality in the Python data ecosystem (surprisingly given the amount of momentum behind Python for data work), but it’s a bit like matplotlib – most people who are using it are using it because it’s the largest among a handful of options, not because we love it

A few months ago after reading our complaints, Abe Gong, the original developer of the library and founder of the company around it, reached out to us to schedule a call. He was generous with his time and resources and very graciously listened to our feedback – this is the conversation we had.

Hopefully folks here find it interesting – and hopefully we captured broader concerns. Let us know if we missed anything important that you would have mentioned
description_plain:
I work for Sparkfish, a data and analytics consultancy serving private equity. 

For context, GE is a data quality library used by data and ML engineers and other folks who work with data; it's the largest library by far in terms of community buy-in and feature set. But like many we've struggled with the difficult learning curve of the GX library and the deprioritization of the open source library vs the paid SaaS product, and we griped about it publicly in various forums and on GH issues. Mainly we've struggled with the steep learning curve, obtuse APIs, lack of sensible defaults, and dated documentation.

It's a great library and surprisingly one of few truly focused on data quality in the Python data ecosystem (surprisingly given the amount of momentum behind Python for data work), but it's a bit like matplotlib -- most people who are using it are using it because it's the largest among a handful of options, not because we love it

A few months ago after reading our complaints, Abe Gong, the original developer of the library and founder of the company around it, reached out to us to schedule a call. He was generous with his time and resources and very graciously listened to our feedback -- this is the conversation we had.

Hopefully folks here find it interesting -- and hopefully we captured broader concerns. Let us know if we missed anything important that you would have mentioned
